awd_titl_txt: Doctoral dissertation research:   Factors influencing generalization and maintenance of cross-category imitation of Mandarin regional variants
awd_abstract_narration:
People change their own language production when hearing others' speech that differs from their own, a process known as phonetic imitation. Imitation of others' speech has been observed between speakers who speak the same dialect and also between speakers who speak different dialects. Previous studies have found that adult speakers who move to a new speech community can partially acquire the accent of the new community. What is less understood, however, is the mechanisms that facilitate or constrain long-term imitation of second-dialect properties. The goal of the current project is to explore the linguistic, situational, and cognitive factors that influence the degree to which imitation of linguistic properties of another dialect is maintained beyond exposure and generalizes to novel words. 

This project will focus on the imitation of dialect-specific properties across two Mandarin regional varieties spoken in Jianshi and Laifeng counties, China. The first experiment will investigate how imitation generalizes to novel monosyllabic words, to reveal the mental representations underlying word processing in Mandarin, i.e., syllables, tones, consonants, vowels, or subsegmental features. The second experiment will examine how the number of token repetitions and lexical contexts containing the variant affect the degree of imitation maintenance and generalization, to reveal the relative contributions of exposure amount and variability to long-term phonetic imitation. The third experiment will use different instructions during post-exposure reading as a way of influencing participants' conscious effort, to investigate the role of automaticity in mediating imitation maintenance and generalization. 

The results of this project will reveal the mechanisms underlying cross-dialect imitation that enable or constrain speakers to maintain and generalize imitation after various exposure environments and in response to different requirements. The results will also provide new insights into the automatic and controlled aspects of imitation, and the representational units connecting speech perception and production. This project has broader implications for the role of phonetic imitation in long-term sound change, and for methods to facilitate second dialect acquisition by improving individuals' ability to imitate, maintain, and generalize new dialect features.

por.por_cntn:
People change their own language production when hearing others' speech that differs from their own, a process known as phonetic imitation. Imitation of others' speech has been observed between speakers who speak the same dialect and also between speakers who speak different dialects. Previous studies have found that adult speakers who move to a new speech community can partially acquire the accent of the new community. What is less understood, however, is the mechanisms that facilitate or constrain long-term imitation of second-dialect properties. The goal of this project was to explore the linguistic, situational, and cognitive factors that influence the degree to which imitation of linguistic properties of another dialect is maintained beyond exposure to that dialect and generalizes to different words that have not been heard in that dialect.

This project focused on the imitation of dialect-specific properties across two Mandarin regional varieties spoken in Jianshi and Laifeng counties, Enshi prefecture, China. The first experiment investigated how imitation generalizes to different monosyllabic words, to reveal the mental representations underlying word processing in Mandarin, i.e., syllables, tones, consonants, vowels, or subsegmental features. The results demonstrate that imitation generalization can occur at syllabic, segmental, and featural levels of representation. The second experiment examined how the number of word repetitions and the number of different words containing the variant affect the degree of imitation maintenance and generalization, to reveal the relative contributions of exposure amount and variability to long-term phonetic imitation. The results show that increased exposure variability is more effective than increased exposure amount in generating stronger generalization, although its facilitative effect is quite limited. The third experiment used different instructions during a post-exposure reading task as a way of influencing participants' conscious effort to imitate, to investigate the role of automaticity in mediating imitation maintenance and generalization. Participants showed the most robust and consistent imitation generalization and maintenance when they were instructed to “say the words like the person you heard,” although some imitation was also observed when participants were instructed “read the words” or “say the words in the way you normally say them.” These results suggest a primary role of speaker control and a secondary role of automaticity in the processes of imitation generalization and maintenance. 

The results of this project provide new insights into the automatic and controlled aspects of imitation and the representational units connecting speech perception and production. This project has broader implications for the role of phonetic imitation in long-term sound change, and for methods to facilitate second dialect acquisition by improving individuals' abilities to imitate, maintain, and generalize new dialect features. This project also provided opportunities for the development of scientific research and mentoring skills for the Co-PI.
